results.contentHtml:
We've setup a sample blog configuration for you to explore and modify. For example, this post can be found in workspace/posts/welcome.md

The next step is probably to explore the documentation and the source code to our site, DADI.cloud as an example project.

Things to try

  1. You are reading workspace/posts/welcome.md. Try changing something in this file, save and refresh to see it updated here.

  2. Create your first datasource. Here is an example of a markdown based one, which is serving the content you are reading.

{
  "datasource": {
    "key": "posts",
    "name": "Blog posts as markdown files.",
    "source": {
      "type": "markdown",
      "path": "./posts"
    },
    "paginate": true,
    "count": 5,
    "sort": {
      "date": -1
    },
    "requestParams": [
      {
        "param": "handle", "field": "handle"
      }
    ]
  }
}
  1. Learn more about DADI API and how you can use it with your new installation of DADI Web

attributes.title: How to change the site name in the header
attributes.author: The DADI Team

results.contentHtml:
To change the name of this example site, look into the config/config.development.json file.

"global": {
  "site": "Your site name",
  "description": "An exciting beginning."
}

Any variables you add in the global object will be available for use in your page templates.
This install uses our pagination helper which we have taken from our Dust.js helpers package. We also recommend including the common Dust.js helpers.

attributes.title: How to create a new page
attributes.author: The DADI Team

results.contentHtml:
Add files your-page-name.json and your-page-name.dust to the workspace/pages folder:

{
  "page": {
    "name": "your_page_name",
    "description": "A description so you know what it does",
  },
  "routes": [
    {
      "path": "/your-page-name"
    }
  ]
}

In the dust file you can put any HTML or make use of the syntax provided by Dust.js.

{>"partials/header" /}

Hello world!

{>"partials/footer" /}
